intro: Hallia glumacea, commonly known as the common hallia, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features lance-shaped leaves with a rough, hairy texture. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in dense clusters, which are borne on slender, leafy stems. Its root system is fibrous and often used in traditional herbal medicine for its purported health benefits. Hallia glumacea thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks.
